greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Irregular triangle in which first row is 1, n-th row (n>1) gives prime factors of n with repetition.
link: N. J. A. Sloane, First 2048 rows of triangle, flattened
S. von Worley (?), Animated Factorization Diagrams, Oct. 2012.
Brent Yorgey, Factorization diagrams, The Math Less Traveled, Oct 05 2012.
maple: P:=proc(n) local FM: FM:=ifactors(n)[2]: seq(seq(FM[j][1],k=1..FM[j][2]),j=1..nops(FM)) end: 1; for n from 2 to 45 do P(n) od; # yields sequence in triangular form; _Emeric Deutsch_, Feb 13 2005
mathematica: row[n_] := Flatten[ Table[#[[1]], {#[[2]]}] & /@ FactorInteger[n]]; Flatten[ Table[ row[n], {n, 1, 45}]] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 01 2011 *)
program: a027746_row n = unfoldr fact n where
fact x = Just (p, x `div` p) where p = a020639 x
(PARI) A027746_row(n,o=[1])=if(n>1,concat(apply(t->vector(t[2],i,t[1]), Vec(factor(n)~))),o) \\ Use %(n,[]) if you want the more natural [] for the first row. - _M. F. Hasler_, Jul 29 2015
for k in [2..45]: v.extend(p for (p, m) in factor(k) for _ in range(m))
xref: Column 1 is A020639, columns 2 and 3 correspond to A014673 and A115561.
A281890 measures frequency of each prime in each column, with A281889 giving median values.
Cf. A175943 (partial products), A265110 (partial row products), A265111.
results.author: _Maghraoui Abdelkader_
